ExplainThis.org Beta

About This

This beta site is an attempt to test the basic idea behind explainthis.org: Users of the news system ask questions to which they don't know the answers; those that can be answered by a web search or by other users should be handled that way. The remaining questions are sorted and ranked by level of user interest. The eventual plan is to recruit journalists, or partner with an existing new organization, to answer the ones that a.) interest the most people and b.) require reporting, investigation and explanation-- in other words, real journalism.

Before we can do that, we have to show that this sorting, filtering and ranking process can be effective. That's what this beta site is for. To learn about the thinking behind explainthis.org see Jay Rosen's original post explaining the idea and this report at Poynter.org.

Explainthis.org is an open source project started by Jay Rosen as part of his Studio 20 program at NYU. Tim Stenovec, a graduate student at NYU, is helping out. The builder of the site is developer Alex Kessinger.

About The Code

The site is built on top of Drupal, it uses a special installation profile called Array Shift. We are storing all the code at GitHub.

You might also notice that this site has real semblance too stackoverflow. That is by design. Stackoverflow has a great method of coalescing a community around questions, and directing knowledgeable users to the questions most users want answers too. We're trying too see if a model like stackoverflows will work for news gathering.

This is an open source, open community project and we would like to encourage anyone who wants to contribute code to do so. Start by forking the repo at GitHub, or contact us if you just want to talk.
